WNI Meninggal Saat Urus Paspor, KBRI Disebut Kesampingkan Perlindungan Migran
01 Nov 2019, 09:49 by ABC
Seorang warga negara Indonesia (WNI) bernama Tamam bin Arsyad ditemukan meninggal dunia saat menunggu proses pengurusan paspornya di Kedutaan Besar Republik Indonesia (KBRI) Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia pada Kamis 31 Oktober 2019. Atas insiden ini, KBRI dianggap belum memprioritaskan perlindungan WNI di luar negeri.
Seorang warga negara Indonesia (WNI) bernama Tamam bin Arsyad (56) ditemukan meninggal dunia saat menunggu proses pengurusan paspornya di Kedutaan Besar Republik Indonesia (KBRI) Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia pada Kamis 31 Oktober 2019. Atas insiden ini, KBRI dianggap belum memprioritaskan perlindungan WNI di luar negeri.
Tamam, bapak beranak tiga yang memegang izin tinggal permanen di Malaysia, disebut-sebut mengalami serangan jantung dan memiliki riwayat penyakit jantung kronis.
"Waktu menunjukkan pukul 18.45. Beberapa WNI sudah bersiap untuk antri pengambilan nomor antrian paspor. Sdr. Tamam bin Arsyad, pemegang IC Merah yang berada di baris paling depan nampak duduk di lantai menunggu pintu dibuka."
"Tiba-tiba yang bersangkutan lunglai dan langsung tergeletak di lantai. Pemohon yang kebetulan berada di belakangnya pun langsung menolong beliau. Setelah ditidurkan di lantai, tidak lama beliau menghembuskan nafas terakhir," tulis KBRI Kuala Lumpur dalam akun resmi media sosialnya, Kamis (31/10/2019) tengah malam.
Dihubungi melalu pesan teks, Koordinator Fungsi Protokol dan Konsuler KBRI Kuala Lumpur, Yusron B. Ambary, mengatakan pihaknya kemudian langsung menghubungi polisi setempat dan ambulans.
Namun, Tamam sudah dinyatakan meninggal dunia.
"Kami sangat berduka dengan wafatnya Almarhum. Tolong dipahami, almarhum meninggal karena penyakit jantung kronis."
"Saat itu tidak ada desak-desakkan, hanya ada segelintir warga, termasuk beliau yang sedang duduk santai menunggu pintu dibuka," ujarnya kepada ABC.
Yusron juga membantah jika Tamam -yang dimakamkan di Pemakaman Islam Kuang, Sungai Buloh, Selangor -telah mengantre di KBRI selama berjam-jam.
"Positif tidak benar," sebutnya.
Di akun Facebook KBRI Kuala Lumpur, postingan berita duka atas meninggalnya Tamam telah dikomentari lebih dari 750 kali. Banyak di antara mereka yang mengecam pelayanan KBRI.

"Nasi sudah jadi bubur...bosan dengan layanan KBRI.slalu saye dengar yg buat splp dipersulit..smoga kluarga arwah diberi ketabahan...," tulis pemilik akun Khaliq Fauzan Fauzan.


"ALFATIHAH...Tolong dong perbaiki sistem antrian Pengambilan nombor Di KBRI dan ubah sikap pegawainya jangan galak2 bersikaplah aopan santun jangan bentak2," sebut sebuah akun bernama Yustina Wiharyati.

Kritikan tajam juga disampaikan Direktur Eksekutif Migrant Care, Wahyu Susilo.
"Saya kira itu ironi di kala Menteri Luar Negeri (Menlu) dalam pidato perdananya menegaskan kembali komitmen perlindungan untuk pekerja migran," tuturnya kepada ABC.
Wahyu mengatakan ada kesenjangan besar antara komitmen perlindungan WNI yang diterapkan Menlu dan para pejabat eselon atas di Kementerian Luar Negeri RI dengan perwakilan yang ada di luar negeri.


WNI yang meninggal saat mengurus paspor tergeletak di lantai depan KBRI Kuala Lumpur. Antara

"Jadi kalau di tingkat Menteri itu effort (usaha) kerjanya itu luar biasa tapi di tingkat perwakilan, itu hampir kerjanya business as usual (tidak ada perubahan)."
"Jadi ya merasa 'ya sudah saya kan melakukan 24 jam' tapi enggak ada penanganan khusus."
"Harusnya kan ada afirmasi khusus untuk mereka yang, kalau diketahui dia jantung, harusnya 'sudah enggak pakai antri, dokumenmu kamu proses, nanti kalau selesai saya antar'. Kan harusnya begitu," papar Wahyu.
Ia menilai staf diplomat di perwakilan belum menganggap pekerjaan pembelaan buruh migran sebagai prioritas.
"Masih menganggap itu sebagai second task of diplomacy, jadi masih menganggap itu pekerjaan sampingan. Padahal polugri (politik luar negeri) kita sudah memprioritaskan perlindungan warga negara sebagai salah satu yang utama."
Wahyu berpendapat kultur mengesampingkan buruh migran sudah berurat akar di perwakilan Indonesia di luar negeri.
"Mereka menganggap bahwa melayani TKI (tenaga kerja Indonesia), melindungi TKI itu pekerjaan tambahan bahkan ada yang menganggap itu pekerjaan sampah."
"Kan seringkali ya, kalau saya ketemu antar Kementerian dan lembaga yang mengurus TKI itu, Sukanya mereka bilang begini 'BNP2TKI (Badan Nasional Penempatan dan Perlindungan Tenaga Kerja Indonesia) yang punya kerjaan, Kemenaker (Kementerian Ketenagakerjaan) yang punya kerjaan, kami yang ketiban beban'."
"Jadi menganggap bahwa itu beban," ungkapnya.

Indonesian citizen dies when taking care of passport, Indonesian embassy is called aside the protection of migrants
Nov 01 2019, 09:49 by ABC
An Indonesian citizen named Tamam bin Arsyad was found dead while waiting for the process of arranging his passport at the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on Thursday 31 October 2019. On this incident, the Indonesian Embassy was considered not to prioritize the protection of Indonesian citizens abroad .
An Indonesian citizen named Tamam bin Arsyad (56) was found dead while waiting for the process of arranging his passport at the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on Thursday 31 October 2019. On this incident, the Indonesian Embassy was considered not to prioritize the protection of Indonesian citizens abroad.
Tamam, a father of three who holds a permanent residence permit in Malaysia, is said to have had a heart attack and has a history of chronic heart disease.
"The time showed 18:45. Several Indonesian citizens were ready to queue to take the passport queue number. Mr. Tamam bin Arsyad, the holder of the Red IC who was in the front row seemed to sit on the floor waiting for the door to be opened."
"Suddenly he was limp and immediately lying on the floor. The applicant who happened to be behind him immediately helped him. After being put to sleep on the floor, he did not breathe last," the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur wrote in his official social media account, Thursday (31 / 10/2019) midnight.
Contacted by text message, the Coordinator of the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur's Protocol and Consular Functions, Yusron B. Ambary, said that he then immediately contacted the local police and ambulances.
However, Tamam has been declared dead.
"We are very saddened by the death of the deceased. Please understand, the deceased died of chronic heart disease."
"At that time there were no pressures, only a handful of residents, including him who was sitting relaxed waiting for the door to open," he told ABC.
Yusron also denied that Tamam - who was buried in the Kuang Islamic Cemetery, Sungai Buloh, Selangor - had been lining up at the Indonesian Embassy for hours.
"Positive is not true," he said.
On the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur's Facebook account, the sad news post about Tamam's death has been commented on more than 750 times. Many of them criticized the service of the Indonesian Embassy.

"The rice has become porridge ... bored with the Indonesian Embassy service. I have always heard that making the SPL has been complicated ... hopefully the souls of the souls will be given fortitude ...," wrote the Khaliq account owner Fauzan Fauzan.


"ALFATIHAH ... Please fix the queue collection system at the Indonesian Embassy and change the attitude of the employees. Don't be so rude as to be polite, don't shout," said an account named Yustina Wiharyati.

Sharp criticism was also conveyed by the Executive Director of Migrant Care, Wahyu Susilo.
"I think that is ironic when the Minister of Foreign Affairs (Menlu) in his inaugural speech reaffirmed the commitment to protect migrant workers," he told ABC.
Wahyu said there was a big gap between the commitment to protect Indonesian citizens applied by the Foreign Minister and top echelon officials at the Indonesian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and representatives abroad.


Indonesian citizen who died while taking care of a passport lying on the front floor of the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur. Among

"So if at the Ministerial level the work effort is extraordinary but at the representative level, it almost works business as usual (no change)."
"So I feel 'yes I have done 24 hours' but there is no special treatment."
"There should be a special affirmation for those who, if they are known to have a heart, should 'not use the queue, you will process your documents, then if I finish sending them, I should,' said Wahyu.
He considered diplomat staff in the representatives did not consider the work of defending migrant workers as a priority.
"Still consider it a second task of diplomacy, so it still considers it a side job. In fact, our foreign policy has prioritized the protection of citizens as one of the main ones."
Wahyu believes that the culture of ruling out migrant workers is entrenched in Indonesian representatives abroad.
"They consider that serving Indonesian Migrant Workers (TKI), protecting Indonesian Migrant Workers is additional work, and some even consider it garbage work."
"So often, yes, if I meet between the Ministries and agencies that take care of the migrant workers, they like to say this' BNP2TKI (National Agency for Placement and Protection of Indonesian Workers) who has work, the Ministry of Manpower (Ministry of Manpower) who has work, we are burdened. '. "
"So assume that it's a burden," he said.
